title: Philips Lights Up National Theatre
text:
23 July 2015 10:43 CET Philips Lights Up National Theatre By Daily Guide 
Africa Regional Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Philips (left), Minister Ofosu-Adjiri (Middle) lighting up the national theatre. 
Philips Ghana Limited, a leading electronics technology firm, has provided a new lighting design for the National Theatre as part of the Philips Cape Town to Cairo Roadshow 2015. 
The move is aimed at lighting up the theatre to highlight its aesthetic beauty with Philips LED innovation lighting solutions and reducing energy consumption by 80 percent. 
General Manager of Philips Lighting West Africa, Felix Darko, speaking at a private cocktail to celebrate the new lighting design for the theatre on Wednesday in Accra, said 'the LED we have provided has a longer lifetime of over 50,000 hours which translate into 14 years of use without any problem which will save the theatre a lot of money.' 
According to him, aside the lighting of the theatre by Philips, the company was also embarking on healthcare activities at the Madina Hospital in Accra and other parts of the country. 
The National TheatreThe programme started six years ago and it would enable Philips to engage with governments and other stakeholders to understand the issues facing Africa and help address them. 
This is the fourth year the Roadshow has visited Accra. Last year, Philips illuminated the Independence Monument. 
Minister of Tourism, Culture and Creative Arts, Elizabeth Ofosu-Adjiri lauded the efforts of Philips in promoting sites and monuments across the world through the Cape Town to Cairo Road Show. 
According to her, since its inception six years ago, the programme has been extended to 11 cities and eight countries. 
She indicated that after 22 years of its existence, the National Theatre was at the top, saying like most theatres, it is embracing innovation and new technology to make it more accessible and friendly to users. 
She was optimistic the illumination of the national threatre by the global electronics giant would enhance the corporate image of the National Theatre. 
Acting Executive Director of the National Theatre, Amy Appiah Frimpong, indicated that globally, performing arts was going through a paradigm shift as a result of 'resource constraints and limited government funding.' 
According to her, this year, the theatre has positioned itself to partner corporate institutions. 
The National Theatre was built by the Chinese Government in 1993 and officially opened its doors to the public in 1994 to primarily promote and develop performing arts in Ghana. 
Since its inception, it has hosted artistic and cultural talents, as well as other high-profiled events. 
Philips' lighting concept is focused on highlighting the significance of the theatre as an architectural masterpiece and a source of national pride. 
The digital LED lighting technology used by Philips creates more light. 
Philips used its Vaya LED lighting solutions to illuminate the National Theatre. 
BY Melvin Tarlue HON. ELIZABETH OFOSU AGYARE- MINISTER FOR TOURISM,CULTURE & CREATIVE ARTS JJ VAN DONGEN-SNR VICE PRESIDENT & CEO PHILIPS AFRICA, HON. ELIZABETH OFOSU AGYARE-MINISTER FOR TOURISM, CULTURE & CREATIVE ARTS, MR. FELIX DARKO- PHILIPS LIGHTING GM, WEST AFRICA
